title: Are ink pen and fountain pen the same? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, most people would agree that if it’s a writing instrument that uses ink, it’s a pen. Otherwise, it’s a pencil, a piece of chalk, or something else. That covers a lot of different types of pens including ball point pens, roller balls, gel pens, felt tip pens, technical pens, and of course, fountain pens, among others. Under ordinary circumstances, the word “ink” is redundant, unless you trying to distinguish the writing instrument from the thing that pigs live in. I would submit that there are other ways to communicate that particular distinction. So, if there is a fountain pen and a pencil laying there, and you say, “hand me the pen”, you will likely get the fountain pen. On the other hand, if there are two pens, a ball point pen, and a fountain pen laying there, and you say “hand me the pen”, the person might ask “which one?”, and if you replied “the ink pen”, they would probably understand that you meant the fountain pen, even though the ball point pen also uses ink, since the fact that it uses real ink is a defining characteristic of a fountain pen. So, yes and no, but mostly no. A fountain pen is a type of ink pen.

My dear … They may be the same while it is about the writing but when it comes with regard to flow of ink standard the ink pen fails at many times because due to air or vacuum that is created during the flow of ink… So in this regard though there may be some similarity in both but they differ according to the flow and the weight of the ink they put on the paper…
All pens are ink pens, but all ink pens are not fountain pens. You question is more analogous to, “Are ferrari's and cars the same?”
